STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
September 1, 2022
Charles Rose
St Joseph County DHHS
692 East Main Street
Centreville, MI 49032
RE: License #: CP750201427
St Joseph County DHHS
692 East Main Street
Centreville, MI 49032
Dear Mr. Rose:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 8/22-
8/29/2022. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and
MISEP requirements, a written corrective action plan is required. It should be noted that
violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP and your contract. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MSA citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, at (616)204-6992.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Holly Austin, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200
121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(269) 330-7082
enclosure
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
INTERIM INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP750201427
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Charles Rose, Administrator
Demetrius Starling, Designee
Name of Facility: St Joseph County DHHS
Facility Address: 692 East Main Street
Centreville, MI 49032
Facility Telephone #: (269) 467-1200
Original Issuance Date: 07/01/1991
Service Types: CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSING
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOMES
1

II. METHODS OF INSPECTION – A. Consultant
Date of On-site Inspection(s): 8/22/2022-8/29/2022
Total No. Of Records No. of Records
Reviewed
No. of current licensed foster homes 31 6
No. of homes pending licensure 4 2

in foster care since last inspection 0 0

since last inspection 0 0

since the last inspection 39 4

since the last inspection 4 2

of foster children) submitted by this agency since the

2

No. of Persons Interviewed:
Licensing Staff 1
Foster Care Staff 2
Independent Living Staff n/a

The following required records were on file and available for review:

METHODS OF INSPECTION – B. Analyst
Total No. No. Visited
No. of licensed foster homes 30 3
No. of unlicensed relatives homes 86 3

Others (please identify person interviewed by role) n/a
3

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12309 Records check.
(3) An agency shall initiate a criminal history check of a
resident minor within 30 days after turning 18 years of age.
1 of 6 open foster home file contained documentation that at the time a home
transferred to the agency, no criminal history check had been completed on a
household member who had turned 18, 3 months before the transfer and the
criminal history checks were not completed after the transfer for another 4 months.
R 400.12312 Foster parent training.
(4) At least 1 adult member of the household shall have
training in and maintain a current certification in first aid
from the American Heart Association or the American Red
Cross or other institution approved by the department.
1 of 6 open foster home files reviewed did not contain documentation that the family
consistently maintained the required certification. At the time of inspection, the
documentation in the file indicated that the certification expired 1/31/22.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection Report 9/9/2020, CAP Approval 10/30/2020
R 400.12325 License recommendation.
(3) Except for an original license, an agency shall recommend to
the department the issuance of a regular license or the
continuation of an active license only when all rules are in
compliance, or both of the following conditions exist:
(a) All non-compliances relating to the recommendation are
correctable.
(b) A written corrective action plan has been developed. The
plan shall be in compliance with all of the following
requirements:
(i) Specify the methods, the persons responsible, the time
frames for correction; methods for ensuring the safety of any
children placed in the home; how continuing compliance will be
maintained once compliance is achieved; consequences if the
corrective action plan is not completed; and what documentation
will be required to demonstrate compliance or completion.
(ii) Require that the corrective action be completed within
six (6) months of being signed.
4

(iii) Be signed and dated by the foster parent and the
agency.
3 of 6 open foster home files contained evaluation reports that documented the
home was in full compliance with no CAP required despite the report documenting
that the family did not practice emergency procedures at the required intervals.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
(a) Submit a special investigation record to the department's
licensing authority within 5 working days in the manner
prescribed by the department.
1 of 6 open foster home files reviewed contained documentation that the required
record was not sent to DCWL timely.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(f) Notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer
guardian ad litem, and courts when applicable, of the change in
placement.
1 of 6 opened foster care case files reviewed did not contain documentation of the
required notification.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child's
record before a change of placement occurs:
(i) That the current foster parent was notified in writing of the
following information:
(i) Not less than 14 calendar days in advance, of the
change, except when prior notification would jeopardize the
child's care or safety. If prior notice is not provided, then the
agency shall notify the foster parent, at the time of the change,
why prior notice was not given.
(ii) Of the current foster parent's rights concerning the
change in placement.
5

1 of 6 open foster care case files reviewed did not contain documentation that a
caregiver was given the required notification of rights regarding a move form, within
the required timeframe.
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(c) A physical examination for each child as follows, unless a
greater frequency is medically indicated:
(i) For a child under 2 years of age, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 3 months before
being placed in foster care or a new physical examination shall
be completed within 30 calendar days after being placed in
foster care.
(ii) For a child 2 years of age or older, a physical
examination shall have been completed within 12 months before
placement or a new physical examination shall be completed
within 30 calendar days after placement.
(iii) A physical examination every 14 months.
1 of 6 open foster care case files reviewed did not contain documentation that the
initial well-child exam was completed within the timeframe outlined in subsection (ii)
1 of 6 open foster care case files reviewed did not contain documentation that a well-
child exam was completed at the required intervals as outlined in subsection (iii)
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/3/2021, CAP Approval 9/15/2021
R 400.12413 Medical and dental care policy.
(1) An agency's medical and dental care policy shall, at a
minimum, include all of the following:
(f) The provision of a dental examination and any treatment
required for each child who is 4 years of age and older,
including both of the following:
(i) A dental examination within 12 months before
placement or a new dental examination shall be completed not
more than 90 calendar days after placement.
1 of 6 open foster care case files reviewed did not contain documentation that the
initial dental exam was completed timely.
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with the following
information prior to the placement or replacement of a
child:
6

4 of 6 open foster care case files reviewed did not contain a 3307 signed by the
initial placement or replacement which documents the receipt of the information
required by subsections, a, b, c, d, e, f, g, h, and i.
1 of 6 open foster care case files reviewed did not contain documentation of an
uploaded 3762 for a placement change as required per subsection j.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHHS policy violation. Please note
that there are additional DHHS Policy requirements that may not be included in
section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional DHHS Policy requirements
except for the following:
ADM 1030 ADOPTION CASE RECORD RETENTION
After adoption finalization, all adoption records are closed. The
records must be kept in separate locked files and shall not be
open to inspection or copying, except as stated in disposition of
records in this item.
For both MDHHS and contracted adoption agency cases, the
local MDHHS office or contracted agency must retain all
adoption case records for one year after finalization of the
adoption. One year (between 12-13 months) past the adoption
finalization date, a contracted adoption agency must send the
original record to the local MDHHS office; copies must not be
maintained by the contracted adoption agency; see licensing
rule R400.12713-
Adoption Placement Record.
The local MDHHS office must forward all records (both MDHHS
adoptions and contracted agency adoptions) to MDHHS central
office within three months of receipt of file. The contracted
adoption agency or local MDHHS office must not retain any
adoption records of MDHHS-supervised children or dispose of
them in any way other than that described in this policy.
Records must be sent to:
Michigan Department of Health and Human Services
Document Control Section
235 S. Grand Avenue
P.O. Box 30037
Lansing, Michigan 48909
Following the finalization of adoption, adoptive family files must
be retained in the local MDHHS office or contracted adoption
agency for three years and may be destroyed after the three-
year period. Any Criminal History Records Information (CHRI)
7

must be maintained and destroyed as outlined in SRM 200,
Fingerprinting.
The finalized adoption files in the office are kept in an unlocked, open shelved
cabinet. There are several files overdue for delivery by at least 3 months.
FOM 722-06B FAMILY TEAM MEETING
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
Case Plan Development/ Reassessment Initial Case Plan (ISP)
- within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar
days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/ Disruption At least three business days
prior to a planned change of placement or no later than three
business days after an unplanned placement change.
Case Closure Within 30 calendar days before the case closure
date or one business day after unplanned court ordered
dismissal.
Documentation The DHS-1105, Family Team Meeting Report, is
used to capture family demographics, FTM logistical
information, needs, strengths, action steps, safety concerns and
the safety plan, and any recommendations made for the family
during the FTM. The DHS-1105, FTM Report, must be
completed for every FTM.
The caseworker must enter the FTM information in MiSACWIS
using the FTM hyperlink within 7 business days of the FTM.
5 of 6 open foster care case files reviewed did not contain documentation that all
required FTMs were held timely and/or did not contain the required FTM forms with
signatures documenting participation.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/3/2021, CAP Approval 9/15/2021
Interim Inspection Report 9/9/2020, CAP Approval 10/30/2020
FOM 722-06H CASE CONTACTS
CONTACT WITH CHILD'S CAREGIVERS
The caseworker must have at least one face-to-face contact in
the caregiver’s home each calendar month. If there is more than
one caregiver, such as a primary and secondary caregiver, the
caseworker must have a face-to-face contact with the
secondary caregiver in the home at least once each quarter.
8

First Two Months after Initial Placement or a Placement
Change
The caseworker must have at least two face-to-face contacts
per month with each child in the first two months following an
initial placement or a placement change.
CHILD IN A PARENTAL PLACEMENT
The contact standards detailed in this section are required
anytime a child is placed with their parent or legal guardian.
Residential or Institutional Setting
When a child is placed in a residential or institutional setting, the
caseworker must have contact with the case manager/therapist
assigned to the child, as described in this section.
MiSACWIS Documentation
Caseworkers must identify whether a private meeting, or safe
sleep verification for infants, occurred for each child participant
in the Participant screen within the Social Work Contact section
of MiSACWIS.
2 of 5 open foster care case files reviewed contained case contact documenting face
to face visits between the worker and youth that had very minimal narrative which
did not document the required quality visit discussions/standards. Additionally, 1 of
the 2 files did not contain documentation that the required CCI staff were present
and met with during the visits and did not clearly document that a private meeting
with the youth occurred each month.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection Report 9/9/2020, CAP Approval 10/30/2020
FOM 722-06J RIGHTS OF CHILDREN IN FOSTER CARE
Within 30 calendar days of removal, the caseworker must review
and explain the DHS-5307, Rights and Responsibilities for
Children and Youth in Foster Care, and the agency's grievance
policy with the child, foster parents, caregivers, and parents. The
caseworker must be prepared to answer any questions the child,
parents, and caregivers may have.
After the document is reviewed the signatures of the child and
caseworker must be obtained. The parent or caregiver must sign
on behalf of the child, if the child is younger than 11 years old or is
unable to sign the document. The caseworker must complete the
information on the last page of the document with the applicable
contact information and provide all participants with a signed copy
and upload a copy to MiSACWIS.
9

Placement Change When a child under age 11 or who is
otherwise unable to sign the DHS-5307 changes placement, the
caseworker must review the DHS-5307 and the agency's
grievance policy with the new caregiver and obtain their
signature on the DHS-5307 within 30 days of the placement
change.
Documentation The DHS-5307 must be reviewed and re-
signed annually. The caseworker must document the review in
the social work contacts, and the caseworker must upload the
DHS-5307 to the Documents hyperlink in MiSACWIS.
5 of 6 open foster care case files reviewed did not contain documentation that all
5307 forms were provided and signed by the required individuals within the required
timeframes.
FOM 722-08D TREATMENT PLANS - AGREEMENT AND SIGNATURES
Once completed and approved, the caseworker must obtain
signatures from the following individuals, as applicable:
 Caseworker
 Supervisor
 Second line supervisor, when siblings in care are placed
apart
 Parents who are a member of a participating household.
 Youth ages 14 and older.
 Foster parents, relative caregivers, and unrelated court-
ordered caregivers.
Parents/legal guardians, youth, and caregivers must check yes
or no for the following when signing the treatment plan:
 I have participated in the development of the Case
Service Plan and the Parent Agency Treatment Plan.
 I agree with the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency
Treatment Plan.
 I have been provided a copy of the Case Service Plan
and Parent Agency Treatment Plan to review, and I will
have the opportunity to express my disagreement with
the Case Service Plan and Parent Agency Treatment
Plan when the information is presented to court.
Note: If a parent or youth is unavailable or refuses to sign the
treatment plan, the caseworker must identify and document
actions needed to secure the parent’s and/or youth’s
participation in service planning and compliance with the
treatment plan.
10

The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
6 of 6 open foster care case files reviewed contained ISP/USPs and/or PATPs which
were either missing required signatures or had signatures that were not obtained
timely. The missing/late signatures include worker, supervisor, parent, youth, and
caregiver.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED as 722-8C
Renewal Inspection Report 9/3/2021, CAP Approval 9/15/2021
Interim Inspection Report 9/9/2020, CAP Approval 10/30/2020
FOM 722-08E FOSTER CARE/JUVENILE JUSTICE ACTION SUMMARY
The DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary is
used to document specific administrative actions or changes in
a case, including: • Child fatality. • Change in caseworker or
organization. • Change in parent contact information. • Foster
care transfer to adoption. • Change in placement. • Temporary
break from placement. • Program or case closing.
COMPLETION REQUIREMENTS The caseworker must
complete the DHS-69, Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action
Summary and upload to MiSACWIS within the timeframe
required for the specified action/change.
Placement Change - Prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement change.
Foster Care/ Juvenile Justice Program/Case Closure -
Within three business days of foster care and/or juvenile justice
program/case closure.
Caseworker/ Organization Change - Within three business
days of change in caseworker and/or organization.
4 of 12 total foster care case files reviewed (6 open and 6 closed) did not contain all
action summaries completed as required. The missing/late action summaries were
required for multiple placement changes and worker changes.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED as 722-9C
Renewal Inspection Report 9/3/2021, CAP Approval 9/15/2021
Interim Inspection Report 9/9/2020, CAP Approval 10/30/2020
FOM 801-03 MEDICAL PASSPORT
For each child in foster care the supervising agency must
maintain a medical passport. Per MCL 722.954c.
11

For children entering foster care, the initial medical passport
must be provided within two weeks of the child/youth's
placement date to the following
 Foster care provider.
 Young adult voluntary foster care (YAVFC) youth/young
adult re-entering foster care.
An updated medical passport is provided to:
 Participating legal parents, if the child is a temporary
court ward.
- Quarterly, while in out-of-home placement.
- At reunification. Subsequent medical passports are not
required after reunification.
 The child’s foster care provider:
- At or prior to each placement.
- Quarterly.
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
Each foster care caseworker who transfers a child's medical
passport to another caseworker must sign and date the medical
passport verifying that s/he has sought and obtained the
necessary information under law and Michigan Department of
Health and Human Services (MDHHS) policy.
Receipt of the medical passport by the above listed parties is
documented in MiSACWIS by uploading the signed and dated
signature page into the Health Profile section.
5 of 6 open foster care case files reviewed did not contain all medical passports. The
missing medical passports included initial, quarterly, worker change, and placement
change signatures.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection Report 9/3/2021, CAP Approval 9/15/2021
Interim Inspection Report 9/9/2020, CAP Approval 10/30/2020
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following area:
 Special Evaluations – Verbal Summary is to be provided to foster parents at the
conclusion of the investigation, not if the investigation is ongoing. The report is
due 15 days from conclusion/verbal summary.
12

 If typed in names are used in place of true electronic signatures, the email
correspondence in which the parent sent the "signed" document should also be
uploaded to verify.
 Policy requires timely upload and identifies the area in which the FTM document
is to be uploaded.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was offered consultation in the following areas:
 Foster parent CPR/First Aid certification must be consistently maintained and
not allowed to expire.
 There must never be more that 4 months between foster parents practice of
emergency procedures.
 Be sure to closely review certification annuals, renewals, and SER’s to ensure
the dates documented are accurate throughout the reports.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
There were no incidents of substantiated corporal punishment during this licensing
period.
The agency has submitted two acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The first CAP was approved on 9/15/2021 and was submitted in response to the
2021 licensing renewal inspection report dated 9/3/2021. The agency staff have
achieved and maintained compliance in 4 of the 10 areas addressed in that CAP.
Agency staff have failed to achieve or maintain compliance in the remaining 6 areas
as evidenced by repeat citations documented in this report which will be addressed
through a new corrective action plan. The agency staff have had difficulty
maintaining compliance in areas such as obtaining signatures timely and timely
completion of forms due to low staffing and frequent placement crisis resulting in
staff having to spend time supervising youth while working on locating appropriate
placement.
The second CAP was approved on 7/28/2022 and was submitted in response to SIR
2022C0112018 in which Rule 400.12404(1) was violated when a minor was placed
in an adult foster care home despite a variance not being approved by LARA or
DCWL. The agency staff are currently in compliance with this CAP as evidenced by
file review of the only youth currently placed in an AFC containing documentation
that the required variances were obtained prior to the placement.
Chief Administrator Assessment – The chief administrator assessment was
discussed during the entrance meeting. The chief administrator accurately identified
13

areas in which staff have struggled to maintain compliance due to staffing and
placement concerns.
Interviews – One of the foster care staff interviewed reported a positive experience
working at the agency, despite the internal and external stressors related to staffing
and local placement concerns. The other foster care staff interviewed expressed
concerns with the ability to communicate and collaborate with upper management
and conveyed concerns with the lack of staff recruitment and retention efforts made
by the agency. No other concerns were raised by staff.
VII. ANALYST CONCERNS
No safety concerns were identified.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon
receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility
continue on a regular license.
9/1/2022
________________________________________
Holly Austin Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
September 1, 2022___________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
14
